moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. c3: White intends to play P-Q4, getting a powerful Pawn center and driving away Black's pieces from that sector.
moves.4... Qe7: This early Queen move is permissible because it does not expose Black's Queen to attack and because it is part of a plan to maintain Black's hold on the center.
moves.5. O-O d6 6. d4 Bb6 7. a4: This move threatens 8 P-R5 winning material. If 8... BxRP? 9 P-Q5 N-N1 10 RxB, or if 8 ,,,NxRP 9 RxN BxR 10 Q-R4 ch and 11 QxB.
moves.7... a6 8. a5 Ba7: Now 8... NxRP could not be countered by 9 RxN: 9... BxR 10 Q-R4 ch P-QN4 11 QxB PxB.
moves.9. h3: To prevent ... B-N5 pinning the Knight.
moves.9... Nf6: White should now play 10 R-K1 and then develop his Q side.
moves.10. dxe5: A very bad move. It opens the diagonal of the Black KB, now trained directly on the White King, and lets the Black Knight reach a splendid post at K4.
moves.10... Nxe5 11. Nxe5: Rather than retreat his B, White exchanges. But the recapture beautifully centralizes the Black Queen.
moves.11... Qxe5 12. Nd2 Bxh3: To break up the Pawns protecting White's King.
moves.14. Kh1 Qxh3+ 15. Kg1 Ng4: Threatening ...Q-R7 mate. A lesson in what happens when the Pawn wall in front of the King is destroyed.
moves.16. Nf3 Qg3+ 17. Kh1 Bxf2: White resigns. The threat is 18... Q-R6 ch 19 N-R2 QxN mate. If 18 RxB NxR mate. If 18 B-B4 QxB White is three Pawns down and has no good way to stop 19... Q-N6.
